summary: pigs are naturally susceptible to three subtypes of influenza A viruses. the virus first encounters mucus, the first barrier of the respiratory tract. the virus reaches the target cells in the mucosal epithelium. the virus is also known to be the cellular receptor of influenza viruses. it is hypothesized that influenza viruses bind to these extracellular receptors, get entrapped in the mucus and then are removed by ciliary clearance [14]–[16]. the effective cleavage may allow the efficient release of virus from the mucus. this contrasts with the findings of Ehre et al. [18] who demonstrated a strong protection of up-regulated mice against A/PR/8/34 H1N1 virus infection. two days before euthanization, the pigs were treated intramuscularly with ceftiofur (Naxcel, releasing SIV from respiratory mucus, but highlights bidirectional synergistic interactions. surfactant protein D (SP-D) binds via a carbohydrate recognition domain in a Ca2+-dependent manner to N-linked carbohydrates present on the HA and NA of the influenza viruses. sIgA is retained at high concentrations in mucus where it can efficiently trap the pathogens. the ability of an influenza virus passing through the mucus may serve as a determinant for influenza virus transmission. swine influenza virus was able to escape from porcine airway mucus. a balance of binding to and releasing from mucin sialic acids may influence how efficiently the virus avoids sticking to mucus. human and swine influenza viruses have a preferential specificity for 2,3-SA. the sialic acids in respiratory mucus secretions may exert an effect on influenza virus transmission. we propose several strategies the influenza viruses may use to overcome the mucus barrier. the use of abundant and ubiquitous molecules as receptors provides the apparent advantage to the virus for allowing infection of multiple cell types and species. this can result in a low minimal infectious dose for initial infection. the slow settle of aerosols in the air can cause prolonged contact of the virus with the respiratory tract which benefits the virus penetration through the mucus layer. the role of influenza virus neuraminidase in cleavage of sialic acid from mucus may shed some light on unravelling the mechanism of influenza pneumonia.
